name: Pfizer takes aim at coronavirus and vaccines market
introduction: Pfizer, a leading developer of coronavirus vaccines, has made progress in a novel oral antiviral for the disease.
content:
Pfizer (NYSE: PFE), a leading developer of coronavirus vaccines, has made progress in a novel oral antiviral for the disease.

The firm has also announced plans to use its experience developing mRNA-based vaccines to become a major force in the broader vaccines market.

In a statement, the New York-based pharma giant said it was progressing to multiple ascending doses in a Phase I study of its antiviral candidate PF-07321332.

The protease inhibitor has demonstrated potent in vitro antiviral activity against SARS-CoV-2, suggesting potential for use in the treatment of COVID-19.

Of particular interest is the fact that the candidate has shown activity against other coronaviruses, suggesting that it could be effective against variants of the disease.

Launching pad

Pfizer is also working on an intravenous antiviral candidate, and believes that the two products could create an “end to end” range of treatments to complement vaccines.

Commenting on the latest trial developments, chief scientific officer Mikael Dolsten said: “Tackling the COVID-19 pandemic requires both prevention via vaccine and targeted treatment for those who contract the virus.”

He added: “Given the way that SARS-CoV-2 is mutating and the continued global impact of COVID-19, it appears likely that it will be critical to have access to therapeutic options both now and beyond the pandemic.”

In collaboration with German firm BioNTech (Nasdaq: BNTX), Pfizer has already led the way in the development of a safe and effective vaccine for the novel coronavirus, with the firms’ mRNA-based shot Comirnaty being rolled out across the globe.

Building on this success, chief executive Albert Bourla said his firm plans to work on more vaccines using mRNA technology, aiming to compete with established vaccines giants such as GlaxoSmithKline (LSE: GSK) and Sanofi (Euronext: SAN).

In an interview with the Wall Street Journal, he said the technology had “proven dramatic impact and dramatic potential,” adding that Pfizer was the “best positioned company right now to take it to the next step.”

Towards this end, Mr Bourla said his firm would leverage the infrastructure it has built up as a part of its collaboration with BioNTech, and hire at least 50 new experts in the technology to keep working on new candidates.
